citations.narrative:
Eight enclosures, housing 20 dogs have an excessive buildup of feces in the outdoor portion of their sheltered enclosures.
In several enclosures the feces had been trampled down from the dogs stepping on it. The licensee stated that the
enclosures had not been cleaned in 3 days.
A buildup of feces could cause the dogs to become soiled and increase the risk of poor health and disease.
Hard surfaces in contact with dogs must be spot-cleaned daily to prevent the accumulation of feces and reduce disease
hazards.

The sheltered part of two enclosures housing 2 German shepherds and 1 standard poodle had an ambient temperature of
38.5 degrees at the time of inspection. The building that serves as the sheltered part of the enclosures has a heating unit,
but the licensee said it had not been plugged in for a few days. According to weather archives, temperatures in the last 48
hours have not been above 40 degrees. No bedding or other methods of conserving heat had been provided. The dogs
appeared healthy and showed no signs of stress. The licensee plugged the heater back in at the time of inspection.
The sheltered part of sheltered housing facilities for dogs and cats must be sufficiently heated and cooled when
necessary to protect the dogs from temperature extremes and to provide for their health and well-being. The ambient
temperature must not fall below 45 °F for more than 4 consecutive hours. Dry bedding or other methods of conserving
body heat must be provided when temperatures are below 50 °F.
To be corrected by: January 2, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
